awd_titl_txt: Dynamics in Anion Clusters and Liquid Jets Using Ultraviolet and Extreme-Ultraviolet Time-Resolved Photoelectron Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Daniel Neumark from the University of California, Berkeley uses ultrafast laser pulses to examine chemical reactions in the gas phase and in aqueous solution.  The gas phase experiments are aimed at understanding the interactions between electrons excited by light and nucleic acid (NA) constituents; this interaction is important in radiation biology and plays a key role in cell mutation, cancer, and cell death.  Complementary experiments in aqueous solution are focusing on the changes of nucleic acid components subsequent to exposure to ultraviolet light. In these experiments, ultraviolet light excites the electrons in the molecules, and the stability of the molecules depends on how rapidly they can convert the light energy into vibrational energy (which can then be dissipated by the surrounding solvent molecules before reactions occur).  The experiments are providing new insights into these relaxation dynamics.  In addition to its implications for radiation biology and other areas of medical technology, this research project provides training for the next generation of scientists.  Professor Neumark promotes the training of female scientists, with the ultimate goal of increasing the representation of women scientists in academia.

This project focuses on complementary studies of chemical reaction dynamics in gas phase ion complexes and liquid water microjets by means of femtosecond time-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy.  The goal of the gas phase experiments is to investigate electron-induced chemistry in nucleobases, nucleotides, and nucleosides.  Starting with binary complexes of iodide anions (I-) bound to a nucleic acid constituent, an electron is transferred from the I- to the nucleic acid (NA) constituent through excitation by an ultraviolet (UV) femtosecond pump pulse.  The subsequent dynamics are followed by photodetaching the excess electron with a femtosecond probe pulse and measuring the resulting photoelectron kinetic energy distribution.  In the liquid water microjet experiments, femtosecond high harmonic generation (HHG)experiments are being developed as a very general probe of reaction dynamics in solution via photoemission at photon energies as high as 100 eV.   Here, for example, a nucleic acid constituent is excited by a UV pump pulse, and time-resolved photoelectron spectra obtained by ionization with the HHG probe pulse tracks the relaxation dynamics of the photoexcited species all the way back to its ground state.  One can also perform time-resolved core level photoemission experiments that rely on the 4d electron binding energy of atomic iodine exhibiting a measureable chemical shift that depends on its overall charge and chemical bonding environment. This method is being used to follow electron recombination with iodine atoms in solution subsequent to charge-transfer-to-solvent excitation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits 

Research over the previous grant period focused on both gas phase and solution phase dynamics of nucleic acid constituents. The gas phase experiments have been primarily concerned with “time-resolved radiation chemistry”, in which the interaction of low energy electrons with bare andmicrohydrated nucleobases was investigated by means of TRPES of I − ·N(H 2 O) 0,1 anion complexes, whereN is a nucleobase. Complementary TRPES experiments were performed on nucleobases, nucleosides,and nucleotides dissolved in liquid water microjets in order to study the electronic relaxation dynamics ofthese species and compare them to previous gas phase work. A femtosecond XUV beamline has beenadded to the liquid jet instrument to enable a new generation of time-resolved experiments.

Gas Phase TRPES experiements

DNA damage induced by low energy electron attachment has been a topic of considerable interestin recent years. Electron attachment to nucleobases and the subsequent formation of transient negativeions (TNIs) of the base has been implicated as the initial step in the damage mechanism. Nucleobases arecapable of forming both a dipole-bound (DB) anion, in which the excess electron is trapped by therelatively large dipole moment of the base, or a conventional valence-bound (VB) anion by electronattachment to the π* orbital of the base. Our group has explored the time-resolved dynamics of electronattachment and transient decay in nucleobases via TRPES of bare and hydrated iodide-nucleobaseclusters, 1 specifically iodide-uracil (I − ·U), iodide-thymine (I − ·T), iodide-adenine (I − ·A), and iodide-uracil-water (I − ·U·H 2 O).

Liquid jet TRPES experiments

The development of the liquid microjet has enabled the study of high vapor pressure liquids invacuum. Femtosecond TRPES, which has traditionally been used in gas phase experiments, 6 has beenapplied to liquid water microjets by several research groups and has been shown to be a powerfultechnique for the interrogation of species in the condensed phase. In these experiments, the solute iselectronically excited by a femtosecond pump pulse and photoionized by a femtosecond probe pulse atvarying pump-probe delays. Photoelectrons are energy-analyzed using a magnetic bottle time-of-flightspectrometer, 42 which provides high collection efficiency and reasonable resolution. With sufficient probeenergy, TRPES can, in principle, track solute dynamics throughout the entire relaxation process andprovide the binding energies of all states involved. In this way, excited state lifetimes can be directlymeasured.

In our laboratory, we have extended previous work on adenine, thymine, and their derivativesalong three directions. TRPE spectra of aqueous adenosine and thymidine monophosphate (AMP andTMP) were measured for the first time and compared to the corresponding nucleobases and nucleosides;results for TMP are shown in Fig. 1. Second, excitation of S 1 in both species at pump energies rangingfrom 4.69 – 5.17eV (265 – 240nm) was followedby ionization at6.20 eV. Thisprobe energy ishigher than hasbeen used inprevious liquid jetwork and enablesone to assess theeffect of probeenergy on theobserved dynamics. Finally, at negative time delays, the role of the pump and probe photons is reversed, so theexperiment investigates dynamics from photoexcitation at 6.20 eV (200 nm). This configuration providedevidence for a new decay channel involving a higher-lying * excited state that is particularlypronounced at negative time delays (6.20 eV pulse first( in TMP, as shown in Fig. 3 around 0.7 eV.

Broader Impacts

I run an active research group and have devoted significant effort to the training and career advancementof female scientists. Five Ph.D. students, two post-doctoral fellows, and two undergraduates have beensupported by this grant. Four of the graduate students (Holly Williams, Alice Kunin, Valerie McGraw,and Megan Asplund), both post-docs (Weili Li and Katharine Lunny), and one of the undergraduates(Erica Liu) are female. Williams received her Ph.D. in 2017 and is now working for Exponent, ascientific consulting company. Kunin received her Ph.D. in 2019 and is now a post-doctoral fellow withProf. Tom Allison at Stony Brook. Li is working at Lam Research, Lunny took a position at PhysicalSciences Inc., and Liu is now a chemistry graduate student at with Bianxiao Cui at Stanford. A formerPh.D. student supported on this project, Sarah King, is in her third year as an Assistant Professor at theUniversity of Chicago. I have also engaged in outreach with undergraduate institutions. I gave the OttLecture at Grand Valley State University in Grand Rapids, Michigan, and gave a seminar at Sonoma StateUniversity in Rohnert Park, California. Both seminars were accompanied by extensive interactions withstudents at these institutions.

 


Last Modified: 10/20/2021
Modified by: Daniel M Neumark
